segments.key_quote: Some of the philosophers who deny all sorts of duality declare that one's own self is responsible for his personal happiness and distress.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the 19th verse of the 17th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, which discusses different philosophical perspectives on the cause of suffering, setting the stage for a discussion of various philosophical schools.
segments.transcript: In this session, we will be discussing from the 19th verse of the 17th chapter of the 1st canto of Shri Madbhagavatam. Kechit Vikalpa Vasana Aahur Aatmanam Aatmanah Daivam Anya Apare Karma Swabhavam Apare Prabhum. The meaning of this verse is: Some of the philosophers who deny all sorts of duality declare that one's own self is responsible for his personal happiness and distress. Others say that superhuman powers are responsible, while yet others say that activity is responsible, and a gross materialist maintains that nature is the ultimate cause. So, dharma, the personality of religion, is replying to Pariksit's question: Who is the cause of your suffering? So, in the previous verse, 18th verse, we discussed that dharma says there are different theories and disciplines in a particular spirit. There are different theories that God has created them in the form of his own existence. Theoretical philosophers who put forward different theories as to the ultimate cause of suffering, and dharma says general people are confused, we do not know which whom to actually accept as correct. So, in the purport, previous verse purport proper, it said generally there are six great philosophers, and I mentioned in the previous session that I shall tell you briefly what are their philosophies, the six great philosophers. Now that is being described by dharma himself, those six philosophers.

segments.key_quote: Jaimini analyzes people can perform either sinful activity or pious activity if they perform pious activity they are going to get enjoyment or happiness if they perform sinful activity they are going to get happiness and if they do not they are going to get suffering or pain or some distress this is jaimini's analysis
segments.summary: The speaker delves into the Karma Mimamsa philosophy of Jaimini, explaining that suffering and enjoyment are direct results of one's past actions, both sinful and pious, and that even gods are bound by the laws of karma.
